blog.name: women-of-ice-and-fire
blog.title: awoiaf women
blog.description:
"Yes. All men must die, but we are not men."
A blog for women in the asoiaf/got universe.

summary: the night wolf & the white wolf | most anticipated reunion in s8 “Arya never seemed to fit, no more than he had… yet she could...
caption:
the night wolf & the white wolf | most anticipated reunion in s8

“Arya never seemed to fit, no more than he had… yet she could always make Jon smile. He would give anything to be with her now, to muss up her hair once more and watch her make a face, to hear her finish a sentence with him.”

summary:
I didn't think this needed to be said, I thought it was a given, but after reading some stuff today:
What happened on the show...
body:
I didn’t think this needed to be said, I thought it was a given, but after reading some stuff today:

What happened on the show Game of Thrones doesn’t somehow magically change what is written in the ASOIAF books that were published years ago. Just because Sansa was given the Jeyne Poole/ Fake Arya storyline on the show does not mean GRRM wanted Sansa to marry Ramsey and have the North rise up to fight over her. That was a D&D invention because they thought the Sansa/Vale plot was too boring and wasted Sophie Turner. D&D actually said that’s why they gave Sansa the Winterfell storyline. When GRRM was still working with D&D on scripts, his notes clearly had “Arya” marrying Ramsey in his outline. Arya is very important to the North in the books and that’s a fact. And the changes D&D made aren’t necessarily approved or ok with GRRM. D&D did not need GRRM approval on all the changes they made. GRRM has stated repeatedly the show is the show, the books are the books and only what appears in the books is canon.

Basically, what appears on the show doesn’t mean that’s what was suppose to happen in the books.

summary: I’m finally watching season 1 of Game of Thrones and I have a question for the people who watch it: Does Sansa get any better?...
body:
I’m finally watching season 1 of Game of Thrones and I have a question for the people who watch it: Does Sansa get any better? I’m a few episodes in and so far:

Joffrey cut a boy’s face with a sword and then swung it around at her sister Ara and then lied about what happened and then the Queen had her innocent pet direwolf be put down

 And she still wants to marry that little snot and she still respects the Queen? 

And she was mad at her father for putting her direwolf down when he didn’t have a choice? And she yelled at Arya while she was getting attacked by Joffrey wielding a sword that Arya was ruining everything?

I get that she’s in her early teens and nobody is perfect but come on

blog.name: buttercuparry
blog.title: Warm Winter Sun
blog.description: If a 12 year old has to save the world then so be it!

body:
You ever think about how Arya Stark took on the name Nan, which in turn is short for Nymeria, and how she escaped Harrenhal (with Hot pie and Gendry) as “Nymeria” and tried to lead her friends across the Riverlands to reach safety??

Cause I do. And it gives me goosebumps. Like we had the Rhoynar princess, Nymeria, lead her people to safety. We have Nymeria the direwolf who is the leader of a huge pack of wolves and then we have little “Nan” leading her friends through the wilds of the Riverland!!

It’s iconic!!

blog.name: faramir-boromir
blog.title: rebellions are built on hope
blog.description: I do not love the bright sword for its sharpness, nor the arrow for its swiftness, nor the warrior for his glory. I love only that which they defend.

blog.name: aqueenofmarble
blog.title: Do I Dare Disturb the Universe?

body:
Why favouritism sucks

Recently I came across a video where J.K Rowling was talking about the movies of Hp with Daniel Radcliffe and Steve Kloves, the writer of the Hp movie scripts.

And something caught my attention. Steve said that his favourite character was not Harry but in fact it was Hermione. And that is when I understood why movie!Hermione is the way she is.

We know in the books Hermione is smart, independent, brave and strong. However she’s still far from perfect. She has lots of flaws, including lack of empathy, emotional breakdowns during times of crisis, arrogance and narrow mindedness.

Albeit, in the movies those negative traits are completely absent. Instead she’s the most sensitive and empathetic of the trio, level headed in times of stress and only acts like a know it all in the first movie which makes her totally unrelatable as a character because she’s just perfect. Now that’s not even my main issue here. What really bothers me is how Hermione’s flawless nature affects other character’s portrayal therefore how they’re perceived by the audience. Aside from the fact that Hermione being too flawless takes away her authenticity, it’s also at the expense of other characters. Best example: Ron Weasley.

A lot of great moments in the books that Ron had were given to Hermione in the movies (like in the 3rd movie when Hermione defended Harry in front of Lupin and Sirius or in the 1st movie when she instantly came up with the spell that saved Ron’s life, even though in the books she freaked out and Ron was the one who calmed her down). So obviously a lot of people that have only watched the movies don’t really care about Ron and think he’s useless. At the same time Hermione is their fave because she’s fierce and smart and sweet (not to mention absolutely beautiful which is also a deviation from the books). And that whole mischaracterization comes from the fact that Hermione was the writer’s fave. She was completely whitewashed since being the writer’s fave results in idealisation and ignorance of flaws.

That is a huge problem that I’ve also encountered in GoT. The character that is the writer’s fave (D&D and Brian Cogman’s in particular) is Sansa Stark. Beforehand I don’t have a problem with book!Sansa. I actually like her. She’s realistic and fully fleshed out. Show!Sansa however is portrayed as way more compassionate, fierce and superior. I wouldn’t even have a problem with that IF it wasn’t at the expense of other characters, particularly Jon and Arya. They took a lot of elements from Arya’s arc that were only relevant and crucial in her story and gave them to Sansa (the lone wolf speech that was only given to Arya and only appears in her chapters because she is the most pack and family-oriented and fully identifies as a wolf, Sansa as the key to the north even though in the books they emphasise Sansa as being the one with the weakest connection to the north and Arya even being the one that got married off to Ramsay though it was not really Arya but that’s what was believed). They also changed Arya and Sansa’s dynamic and turned Arya into the “problem” by making her mean and resentful towards Sansa despite it being the other way around in the books. That was in order to make Sansa more likeable and sympathetic.

Moreover, Sansa is also shown as the “smartest Stark” and clearly superior to the rest. But that’s really not true at all. Arya is incredibly smart and perceptive, she is good at math and knows how to solve problems with cunning and stealth, Jon is a military strategist and Bran is also very wise and insightful. In the show however, they tend to dumb down all the characters that interact with Sansa in order to establish her intelligence and intellectual superiority. (I mean Sansa knowing more about armor than actual armorers that are dealing with this their whole life? Really?)

That again is the consequence of favouritism. It has come to the point where I wouldn’t even be surprised anymore if Sansa suddenly knew more about ruling and warfare than Dany even though she’s a Queen and knows all about conquering (at least more than Sansa).

As I’ve already mentioned my problem is not really Sansa’s flawlessness it’s more how that affects other characters’ story lines and personalities. If Arya and Jon were still true to their book counterparts when interacting with Sansa, I would even be fine with that. But that’s not the case. Jon turns into a dumb idiot and Arya an irrational rage ball when sharing a scene with Sansa. And that change is solely made to prop up Sansa because she’s the show writers’ favourite character (which is also a contradiction in itself because if she was their fave then why would they change her and her story line?).

My point is favouritism does not just negatively affect the character that’s favoured but also every other character.

Beforehand I don’t have a problem with book!Sansa. I actually like her. She’s realistic and fully fleshed out. Show!Sansa however is portrayed as way more compassionate, fierce and superior. I wouldn’t even have a problem with that IF it wasn’t at the expense of other characters, particularly Jon and Arya. They took a lot of elements from Arya’s arc that were only relevant and crucial in her story and gave them to Sansa (the lone wolf speech that was only given to Arya and only appears in her chapters because she is the most pack and family-oriented and fully identifies as a wolf, Sansa as the key to the north even though in the books they emphasise Sansa as being the one with the weakest connection to the north and Arya even being the one that got married off to Ramsay though it was not really Arya but that’s what was believed). They also changed Arya and Sansa’s dynamic and turned Arya into the “problem” by making her mean and resentful towards Sansa despite it being the other way around in the books. That was in order to make Sansa more likeable and sympathetic.

Moreover, Sansa is also shown as the “smartest Stark” and clearly superior to the rest. But that’s really not true at all. Arya is incredibly smart and perceptive, she is good at math and knows how to solve problems with cunning and stealth, Jon is a military strategist and Bran is also very wise and insightful. In the show however, they tend to dumb down all the characters that interact with Sansa in order to establish her intelligence and intellectual superiority. (I mean Sansa knowing more about armor than actual armorers that are dealing with this their whole life? Really?)

That again is the consequence of favouritism. It has come to the point where I wouldn’t even be surprised anymore if Sansa suddenly knew more about ruling and warfare than Dany even though she’s a Queen and knows all about conquering (at least more than Sansa).

As I’ve already mentioned my problem is not really Sansa’s flawlessness it’s more how that affects other characters’ story lines and personalities. If Arya and Jon were still true to their book counterparts when interacting with Sansa, I would even be fine with that. But that’s not the case. Jon turns into a dumb idiot and Arya an irrational rage ball when sharing a scene with Sansa. And that change is solely made to prop up Sansa because she’s the show writers’ favourite character (which is also a contradiction in itself because if she was their fave then why would they change her and her story line?).

My point is favouritism does not just negatively affect the character that’s favoured but also every other character.

blog.name: rainhadaenerys
blog.title: Daenerys Targaryen is the love of my life

summary: I hope you know Google's autocomplete function varies from person to person and is based on your past searches. If you want a...
question: I hope you know Google's autocomplete function varies from person to person and is based on your past searches. If you want a standardized result you need to go on anonymous. On mine, on anonymous, it autocompletes as 'dany is jon's aunt' and 'arya is batman'. Not that bad?
answer:
It seems that someone got pressed over my results showing the sexism in the fandom! For anyone wondering, anon is referring to this post.

So let’s see what Google says about the autocomplete (source):

Where search predictions come from

  • The terms you’re typing.
  • Relevant searches you’ve done in the past (if you’re signed in to your Google Account and have Web & App Activity turned on).
  • What other people are searching for, including Trending stories . Trending stories are popular topics in your area that change throughout the day. Trending stories aren’t related to your search history. To see Trending stories, go to Google Trends.

The Google Search autocomplete is based on your past searches only if you are signed in to your Google Account. To give an example, here’s a search that I did and here’s what Google showed me:

I was searching about Jungian Archetypes, and as you can see being pointed by the red arrow, I was logged in my account. Notice how the suggestions based in my previous searches appear in purple, and there’s a button that allows me to remove that suggestion from my search history. Now, when I logged off of my account, this is what happens:

See? No purple suggestions anymore. In my original post about the Google Search Autocomplete, there was no purple suggestions either, none of those suggestions were based on my past searches (I can guarantee you that I don’t search things like “Daenerys is a villain”).

But to make you happy, I did some searches again on anonymous (not all of them because that took a lot of work):

See? The results are pretty much the same. Daenerys “is overrated”, “is going to die”, “is a bad ruler”, “is the villain”, “is mad” and “is a tyrant”.

Now let’s see Arya:

Not as bad as Dany, but just like I said in my original post, “Arya Stark is overrated” is there.

For Sansa, “so stupid” is still there. And we also have “Sansa is better than Arya”, because apparently her fandom is incapable of appreciating a female character without tearing down others, and this tendency to see other women as rivals is something that comes from our patriarchal society.

Now let’s see some male villains:

Jaime is “a good guy” and “the hero”.

Robert Baratheon “was right”, “was a good king” and “was the best king”. There’s also the accusation of being a “bad king”, but Robert was a bad king.

Sandor Clegane is “a good guy”, “the best character” and “my favorite”. There’s also “is he evil?”, but that’s in line with his character.

Theon Greyjoy is “my favorite character” and “the best character”.

Tywin Lannister is “the best character”, “a badass”, “not evil” and “good”.

The results were all pretty much the same. I did say in my original post that I am from Brazil, so maybe people in other areas have different results. I also said that the results change with time. But I think it’s pretty safe to say that this fandom is misogynistic, or else we wouldn’t see a female hero being treated as worse than all of the male villains.

blog.name: twijfelaar
blog.title: Stick 'em with the pointy end.
blog.description: Lesbian, cares for all the female characters. Right now Rey is Bae, I became Star Wars trash over christmas break. Shipping all the ladies, loving all the ladies. I have a thing for muscles.

tags: keep your shitty fanfiction away from my canon please
summary: If I see one more person claiming Jon cares for some of his family members and not all of them. This is what he thinks about...
caption:
If I see one more person claiming Jon cares for some of his family members and not all of them.

This is what he thinks about just as he is about to ignore his vows and to save the only family member he still has left. 

So fuck off with your, Jon doesn’t care about Sansa, he doesn’t care about Arya. Jon cares for his sisters, both of them.

Stop trying to see some Stark family feud, the only people thinking that, do not know the Starks or seem to think every family has to be like the Lannisters to be interesting. (Looking at you tv show writers and fans)

summary: Rhaenys Targaryen was: 1. a warrior 2. loved the smallfolk If the Stark stans want to compare her with a Stark character (which...
body:
Rhaenys Targaryen was:

1. a warrior

2. loved the smallfolk

If the Stark stans want to compare her with a Stark character (which I don’t find necessary since most of them claim to hate all the Targaryens) guess which Stark girl fits the description.

Yup, it’s Arya.

summary:
The Hound, dying: once you’ve hit rock bottom, the only way for you to go is up
Arya, stealing his silver: you underestimate me....
body:
The Hound, dying: once you’ve hit rock bottom, the only way for you to go is up

Arya, stealing his silver: you underestimate me. I’ve brought my pickaxe and I’m ready to dig.
